sections.doco:title: Classes of structures \\ and their generic limits
sections.doco:abstract:
We consider an influence of potential structures for
diagrams in generic constructions to their topological limits. The
structures for intersections of neighborhoods and cardinalities of
these intersections are defined.
sections.doco:subtitle: Classes of structures and their generic limits
sections.doco:keywords: generic class, generic structure, generic limit, neighborhood
doco:chapter:
We begin by discussing collections of sentence and formulas in
first order logic over a language $\Sigma$. Thus, as usual,
$\vdash$ means proof from no hypotheses deducing $\vdash\varphi$
for a formula $\varphi$ of language $\Sigma$, which may contain
function symbols and constants. If deducing $\varphi$, hypotheses
in a set $\Phi$ of formulas can be used, we write
$\Phi\vdash\varphi$. Usually $\Sigma$ will be fixed in context and
not mentioned explicitly.

Below we write $X,Y,Z,\ldots$ for finite sets of~variables, and
denote by $A,B,C,\ldots$ finite sets of elements, as well as
finite sets in structures, or else the structures with finite
universes themselves. In diagrams, $A,B,C,\ldots$ denote finite
sets of constant symbols disjoint from the constant symbols in
$\Sigma$ and $\Sigma(A)$\index{$\Sigma(A)$} is the language with
the constants from $A$ adjoined. $\Phi(A),\Psi(B),{\rm X}(C)$
stand for {\em
$\Sigma$-diagrams}\index{Diagram}\index{$\Sigma$-diagram}(of sets
$A$, $B$, $C$), that is, {\em consistent sets of $\Sigma(A)$-,
$\Sigma(B)$-, $\Sigma(C)$-sentences}, respectively.

Below we assume that for any considered diagram $\Phi(A)$, if
$a_1,a_2$ are distinct elements in $A$ then $\neg(a_1\approx
a_2)\in\Phi(A)$. It means that if $c$ is a constant symbol in
$\Sigma$, then there is at most one element $a\in A$ such that
$(a\approx c)\in\Phi(A)$.

\begin{definition}\label{dfg1} {\rm \cite{Su073, SuLP, SuCCMCT} We denote by
$[\Phi(A)]^A_B$\index{$[\Phi(A)]^A_B$} the diagram $\Phi(B)$
obtained by replacing a subset $A'\subseteq A$ by a set
$B'\subseteq B$ of constants disjoint with $\Sigma$ and with
$|A'|= |B'|$, where $A\setminus A'=B\setminus B'$. Similarly we
call the consistent set of formulas denoted by
$[\Phi(A)]^A_X$\index{$[\Phi(A)]^A_X$} the type $\Phi(X)$ if it is
the result of a bijective substitution into $\Phi(A)$ of variables
of $X$ for the constants in $A$. In the case, we say that
$\Phi(B)$ is a {\em copy}\index{Copy of diagram} of $\Phi(A)$ and
a {\em representative}\index{Representative of type} of $\Phi(X)$.
We also denote the diagram $\Phi(A)$ by
$[\Phi(X)]^X_A$.\index{$[\Phi(X)]^X_A$}

Let $\Sigma$ be a language. We say that $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ (or
${\bf D}_0$) is {\em generic}\index{Class!generic} or {\em
generative}\index{Class!generative} if ${\bf D}_0$ is a class of
$\Sigma$-diagrams of finite sets so that ${\bf D}_0$ is partially
ordered by a binary relation $\preceq$ such that $\preceq$ is
preserved by bijective substitutions, i.~e., if
$\Phi(A)\preceq\Psi(B)$, and $A'\subseteq B'$ such that
$[\Phi(A)]^A_{A'}=\Phi(A')$ and $[\Psi(B)]^B_{B'}=\Psi(B')$ are
defined, then $[\Phi(A)]^A_{A'}$, $[\Psi(B)]^B_{B'}$ are in ${\bf
D}_0$ and $[\Phi(A)]^A_{A'}\preceq[\Psi(B)]^B_{B'}$. Furthermore:

%\medskip
(i) results of bijective substitutions $[\Phi(A)]^A_X$ of sets $X$
of variables for constants in $A$ into diagrams $\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0$ (over all sets $A$) form a countable set;

%\medskip
(ii) if $\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0$ then for any quantifier free formula
$\varphi(\bar{x})$ and any tuple $\bar{a}\in A$ either
$\varphi(\bar{a})\in\Phi(A)$ or $\neg\varphi(\bar{a})\in\Phi(A)$;

%\medskip
(iii) if $\Phi\preceq\Psi$ then $\Phi\subseteq\Psi$;

%\medskip
(iv) if $\Phi\preceq{\rm X}$, $\Psi\in{\bf D}_0$, and
$\Phi\subseteq \Psi\subseteq{\rm X}$, then $\Phi\preceq\Psi$;

%\medskip
(v) some diagram $\Phi_0(\emptyset)$ is the least element of the
system $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$;

%\medskip
(vi) (the \emph{$d$-amalgamation
property}\index{Property!$d$-amalgamation}) for any diagrams
$\Phi(A),$ $\Psi(B),$  ${\rm X}(C)\in{\bf D}_0$, if there exist
injections $f_0\mbox{\rm : }A\to B$ and $g_0\mbox{\rm : }A\to C$
with $[\Phi(A)]^A_{f_0(A)}\preceq\Psi(B)$ and
$[\Phi(A)]^A_{g_0(A)}\preceq{\rm X}(C)$, then there are a diagram
$\Theta(D)\in{\bf D}_0$ and injections $f_1\mbox{\rm : }B\to D$
and $g_1\mbox{\rm : }C\to D$ for which
$[\Psi(B)]^B_{f_1(B)}\preceq\Theta(D)$, $[{\rm
X}(C)]^C_{g_1(C)}\preceq\Theta(D)$ and $f_0\circ f_1=g_0\circ
g_1$; the diagram $\Theta(D)$ is called the {\em
amalgam}\index{Amalgam} of $\Psi(B)$ and ${\rm X}(C)$ over the
diagram $\Phi(A)$ and the four $(f_0,g_0,f_1,g_1)$;

%\medskip
(vii) (the \emph{local realizability
property}\index{Property!local realizability}) \ \  if \ \
$\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0$ \ \  and \ \ $\Phi(A)\vdash\exists
x\:\varphi(x)$, then there are a diagram $\Psi(B)\in{\bf D}_0$,
$\Phi(A)\preceq\Psi(B)$, and an element $b\in B$ for which
$\Psi(B)\vdash\varphi(b)$;

%\medskip
(viii) (the \emph{$d$-uniqueness
property}\index{Property!$d$-uniqueness}) for any diagrams
$\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in {\bf D}_0$ if $A\subseteq B$ and the set
$\Phi(A)\cup\Psi(B)$ is consistent then
$\Phi(A)=\{\varphi(\bar{b})\in\Psi(B)\mid\bar{b}\in A\}$.

%\medskip
A diagram $\Phi$ is called a \emph{strong
subdiagram}\index{Subdiagram strong} of a diagram $\Psi$ if
$\Phi\preceq\Psi$. A diagram $\Phi(A)$ is said to be ({\em
strongly}) {\em embeddable}\index{Diagram!embeddable in a
diagram}\index{Diagram!embeddable in a diagram!strongly} in a
diagram $\Psi(B)$ if there is an injection $f\mbox{\rm : }A\to B$
such that $[\Phi(A)]^A_{f(A)}\subseteq\Psi(B)$
($[\Phi(A)]^A_{f(A)}\preceq\Psi(B)$). The injection $f$, in this
instance, is called \ a~({\em strong}) {\em embedding} of diagram
$\Phi(A)$ in diagram\index{Embedding!of diagram in
diagram}\index{Embedding!of diagram in diagram!strong} $\Psi(B)$
and is denoted by $f\mbox{\rm :
}\Phi(A)\to\Psi(B)$\index{$f\mbox{\rm : }\Phi(A)\to\Psi(B)$}. A
diagram $\Phi(A)$ is said to be ({\em strongly}) {\em
embeddable}\index{Diagram!embeddable in a
structure}\index{Diagram!embeddable in a structure!strongly} in a
structure $\mathcal{M}$ if $\Phi(A)$ is (strongly) embeddable in
some diagram $\Psi(B)$, where $\mathcal{M}\models\Psi(B)$. The
corresponding embedding $f\mbox{\rm : }\Phi(A)\to\Psi(B)$, in this
event, is called a ({\em strong}) {\em embedding} of diagram
$\Phi(A)$ in structure\index{Embedding!of diagram in
structure}\index{Embedding!of diagram in structure!strong}
$\mathcal{M}$ and is denoted by~$f\mbox{\rm :
}\Phi(A)\to\mathcal{M}$.\index{$f\mbox{\rm :
}\Phi(A)\to\mathcal{M}$}

Let ${\bf D}_0$ be a class of diagrams, ${\bf P}_0$ be a class of
structures of some language, and $\mathcal{M}$ be a structure in
${\bf P}_0$. The class ${\bf D}_0$ is {\em cofinal}\index{Class!of
diagrams!cofinal in a structure} in the structure $\mathcal{M}$ if
for each finite set $A\subseteq M$, there are a finite set $B$,
$A\subseteq B\subseteq M$, and a~diagram $\Phi(B)\in{\bf D}_0$
such that $\mathcal{M}\models\Phi(B)$. The class ${\bf D}_0$ is
{\em cofinal}\index{Class!of diagrams!cofinal in a class of
structures} in~${\bf P}_0$ if~${\bf D}_0$ is cofinal in every
structure of ${\bf P}_0$. We denote by ${\bf K}({\bf
D}_0)$\index{${\bf K}({\bf D}_0)$} the class of all structures
$\mathcal{M}$ with the condition that ${\bf D}_0$ is cofinal in
$\mathcal{M}$, and by~${\bf P}$ a~subclass of ${\bf K}({\bf D}_0)$
such that each diagram $\Phi\in{\bf D}_0$ is true for some
structure in ${\bf P}$.

Now we extend the relation $\preceq$ from the generic class $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$ to a class of subsets of structures in the class
${\bf K}({\bf D}_0)$.

Let $\mathcal{M}$ be a structure in ${\bf K}({\bf D}_0)$, $A$ and
$B$ be finite sets in $\mathcal{M}$ with $A\subseteq B$. We call
$A$ a {\em strong subset}\index{Subset strong} of the set $B$ (in
the structure $\mathcal{M}$), and write $A\preceq B$, if there
exist diagrams $\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in {\bf D}_0$, for which
$\Phi(A)\preceq\Psi(B)$ and $\mathcal{M}\models\Psi(B)$.

A finite set $A$ is called a {\em strong subset} of a set
$M_0\subseteq M$ (in the structure $\mathcal{M}$), where
$A\subseteq M_0$, if $A\preceq B$ for any finite set $B$ such that
$A\subseteq B\subseteq M_0$ and $\Phi(A)\subseteq\Psi(B)$ for some
diagrams $\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in {\bf D}_0$ with
$\mathcal{M}\models\Psi(B)$. If $A$ is a strong subset of $M_0$
then, as above, we write $A\preceq M_0$. If $A\preceq M$ in
$\mathcal{M}$ then we refer to $A$ as a~{\em self-sufficient
set}\index{Set!self-sufficient} (in $\mathcal{M}$).}
\end{definition}
Notice that, by the $d$-uniqueness property, the diagrams
$\Phi(A)$ and $\Psi(B)$\ specified \ in \ the \ definition \ of \
strong \ subsets \ are \ defined uniquely. A diagram
$\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0$, corresponding to a self-sufficient set $A$
in $\mathcal{M}$, is said to be a {\em self-sufficient
diagram}\index{Diagram!self-sufficient}(in $\mathcal{M}$).

\begin{definition}\label{dfg2} {\rm \cite{Su073, SuLP, SuCCMCT} A class $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$ possesses the {\em joint embedding property}
(JEP)\index{Property!joint embedding} if for any diagrams
$\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in{\bf D}_0$, there is a diagram ${\rm
X}(C)\in{\bf D}_0$ such that $\Phi(A)$ and $\Psi(B)$ are strongly
embeddable in ${\rm X}(C)$.}
\end{definition}
Clearly, every generic class has JEP.

\begin{definition}\label{dfg3} {\rm \cite{Su073, SuLP, SuCCMCT} A structure
$\mathcal{M}\in{\bf P}$ has {\em finite
closures}\index{Structure!having finite closures} with respect to
the class $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ if any finite set $A\subseteq M$
is contained in some self-sufficient set in $\mathcal{M}$. A class
${\bf P}$ has {\em finite closures}\index{Class!having finite
closures} with respect to the class $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ if each
structure in ${\bf P}$ has finite closures.}
\end{definition}
Clearly, at most countable structure $\mathcal{M}$ has finite
closures with respect to \ $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$\ if and only if
\ $M=\bigcup\limits_{i\in\omega}A_i$\ for \ some \
self-sufficient \ sets \ $A_i$\ with \ $A_i\preceq A_{i+1}$,
$i\in\omega$.

\begin{definition}\label{dfg4} {\rm \cite{Su073, SuLP, SuCCMCT} A structure $\mathcal{M}\in{\bf
K}({\bf D}_0)$ is {\em $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic}\index{Structure!$({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic}, or a {\em generic limit for the class
$({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$}\index{Limit generic} and denoted by ${\rm
glim}({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$,\index{${\rm glim}({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$}
if it satisfies the following conditions:

(a) $\mathcal{M}$ has finite closures;

(b) if $A\subseteq M$ is a finite set, $\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in{\bf
D}_0$, $\mathcal{M}\models\Phi(A)$ and $\Phi(A)\preceq\Psi(B)$,
then there exists a set $B'\preceq M$ such that $A\subseteq B'$
and $\mathcal{M}\models\Psi(B')$.}
\end{definition}
Given any generic class $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$,  we can embark on a
step-by-step construction of a $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic
structure $\mathcal{M}$ of cardinality $\leq{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}$ using $d$-amalgamations and local
realizabilities.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm1} \cite{Su073, SuLP, SuCCMCT} For any generic class $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$, there exists a $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic
structure.
\end{theorem}\begin{definition}\label{dfg5} {\rm
A generic class $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ is {\em
self-sufficient}\index{Class!generic!self-sufficient} if the
following {\em axiom of self-sufficiency}\index{Axiom!of
self-sufficiency} holds:

(ix) if $\Phi,\Psi,{\rm X}\in{\bf D}_0$, $\Phi\preceq\Psi$, and
${\rm X}\subseteq \Psi$, then $\Phi\cap{\rm X}\preceq{\rm X}$.}
\end{definition}\begin{theorem}\label{thm2} \cite{Su073, SuLP, SuCCMCT} Let $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ be a
self-sufficient class, $\overline{\mathcal{M}}$ be a~$({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic \ structure, \ and \ ${\bf K}$ \ be \ the \
class \ of \ all \ models \ of~$T={\rm
Th}(\overline{\mathcal{M}})$ which has finite closures. Then the
generic structure $\overline{\mathcal{M}}$ is
$\omega$-homogeneous. \end{theorem}
Thus, since any $\omega$-homogeneous can be considered as generic
with respect to a generic class with complete diagrams, a
structure $\mathcal{M}$ is $\omega$-homogeneous if and only if it
is generic for an appropriate self-sufficient generic class $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$.

Let $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ be a self-sufficient generic class of a
language $\Sigma$ and $\Phi(A)$ be a diagram in~${\bf D}_0$.
Denote by $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$\index{$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$} the class
$\{\mathcal{M}\mid\mathcal{M}\models\Phi(A)\}$ of all {\em
potential}\index{Structure!potential} structures $\mathcal{M}$, of
the language $\Sigma$, containing $A$ and satisfying $\Phi(A)$.

By the definition, the classes $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$ are neighborhoods
for structures satisfying $\Phi(A)$. Some variations of these
neighborhoods and related topologies introduced in \cite{HjKe}.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop1} For any consistent diagrams
$\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in{\bf D}_0$, $\Phi(A)\subseteq\Psi(B)$ if and
only if $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]$, moreover,
$\Phi(A)\subset\Psi(B)$ if and only if
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]\supset[\![\Psi(B)]\!]$.
\end{proposition}{\em Proof.} If $\Phi(A)\subseteq\Psi(B)$ then for any structure
$\mathcal{M}$ with $\mathcal{M}\models\Psi(B)$, we have
$\mathcal{M}\models\Phi(A)$. Thus
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]$. Now if
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]$ then $A\subseteq B$
since otherwise there are structures $\mathcal{M}$ with
$\mathcal{M}\models\Psi(B)$ and $A\not\subseteq M$ whence
$\mathcal{M}\in[\![\Psi(B)]\!]\setminus[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$. Since
$A\subseteq B$, by Axioms of self-sufficiency and $d$-uniqueness,
we get $\Phi(A)\cap\Psi(B)=\Phi(A)$. Thus
$\Phi(A)\subseteq\Psi(B)$. Finally, if $\Phi(A)\subset\Psi(B)$
then, by $d$-uniqueness, $A\subset B$ and there is a structure
$\mathcal{M}$ with $\mathcal{M}\models\Phi(A)$ and $B\not\subseteq
M$, whence
$\mathcal{M}\in[\![\Phi(A)]\!]\setminus[\![\Psi(B)]\!]$. \Endproof%\medskip
By the definition, classes $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$ are closed under
isomorphisms and it is natural to consider isomorphism types
instead of structures in $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$.

For a diagram $\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0$ we denote

\medskip$\bullet$ by $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm
Iso}$\index{$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$} the quotient of
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$ by the isomorphism relation;

\medskip$\bullet$ by $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\lambda}$\index{$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},\lambda}$} the
the restriction of $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$ to the isomorphism
types of structures of cardinality $\leq\lambda$;

\medskip$\bullet$ by $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h}$\index{$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h}$} the restriction of
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$ to the isomorphism types of
$\omega$-homogeneous structures;

\medskip$\bullet$ by $[\![\Phi(A)\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}$ the
restriction of $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h}$ to the isomorphism
types of structures of cardinality $\leq\lambda$.

\medskip
By the definition, we have the following relations:
\begin{equation}\label{eq1}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\supseteq[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\lambda},\end{equation}\begin{equation}\label{eq2}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\supseteq[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h},
\end{equation}\begin{equation}\label{eq3}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\lambda}\cap[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h}=
[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}).
\end{equation}
The inclusion (\ref{eq1}) is strict if and only if
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$ contains infinite structures or $\Phi(A)$ is
satisfied by a finite structure having a cardinality $>\lambda$.
The strict inclusion (\ref{eq2}) means that $\Phi(A)$ is satisfied
by a structure $\mathcal{M}$ having a theory ${\rm
Th}(\mathcal{M})$ with models which are not $\omega$-homogeneous.
In particular, that theory is not totally categorical.


Since there are generic structures of a cardinality $\leq{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}$ and each structure of cardinality $\leq{\rm max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}$ has a $\omega$-homogeneous
elementary extension preserving the cardinality $\leq{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}$, by Proposition \ref{prop1} and relations
(\ref{eq1})--(\ref{eq3}) we have

\begin{corollary}\label{cor1}  For any consistent diagrams
$\Phi(A),\Psi(B)\in{\bf D}_0$, the following conditions are
equivalent:

$1)$ $[\Phi(A)]^A_{A'}\subseteq\Psi(B)$ for $A'\subseteq B$;

$2)$ $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{\rm
Iso}$;

$3)$ $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}}\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}}$;

$4)$ $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h}\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h}$;

$5)$ $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}}\supseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}}$.
\end{corollary}
At the same time, strict inclusions
$[\Phi(A)]^A_{A'}\subset\Psi(B)$ may not imply
$[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\supset[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$. For
instance, if $\Phi(A)$ contains a totally categorical countable
theory $T$, of language $\Sigma$, then $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$
and $[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$ contain unique element for every
cardinality $\lambda\geq\omega$, and all models are infinite.
Thus, $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}=[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$ as
well as $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},\omega}=[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\omega}$, $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h}=[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h}$ and $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\omega}=[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\omega}$.

\medskip
As classes $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]$ are neighborhoods for structures
satisfying $\Phi(A)$, classes $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$,
$[\![\Phi(A)\!]_{{\rm Iso},\lambda}$, $[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h}$, $[\![\Phi(A)\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}$ form
neighborhoods for corresponding isomorphism types.

Let $\Phi(A),\Psi(B),{\rm X}(C),\Theta(D)\in{\bf D}_0$, and
$\Theta(D)$ be an amalgam of $\Psi(B)$ and ${\rm X}(C)$ over
$\Phi(A)$. The neighborhood $[\![\Theta(D)]\!]$,
$[\![\Theta(D)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$ and its restrictions are called {\em
amalgams}\index{Amalgam} of corresponding neighborhoods of
$\Psi(B)$ and ${\rm X}(C)$ over neighborhoods of $\Phi(A)$. By
Corollary \ref{cor1}, we have the following inclusions for ${\rm
Iso}$-neighborhoods: $[\![\Theta(D)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\subseteq[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\cap[\![{\rm X}(C)]\!]_{\rm Iso},$$[\![\Psi(B)]\!]_{\rm Iso}\cup[\![{\rm X}(C)]\!]_{\rm
Iso}\subseteq[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}.$ Similar inclusions hold
for $\lambda$- $h$- and $(h,\lambda)$-neighborhoods. Thus, for the
generic class $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$, there are partially ordered,
by inclusion, downward directed sets $\mathfrak{A}_{\rm Iso}$,
$\mathfrak{A}_{{\rm Iso},\lambda}$, $\mathfrak{A}_{{\rm Iso},h}$,
$\mathfrak{A}_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}$(with the greatest elements
corresponding to $\Phi_0(\emptyset)$) of corresponding
neighborhoods, each of which consists of isomorphism types of
potential structures and contains the isomorphism type of $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structure $\mathcal{M}$(for
$\lambda\geq|M|$).

Below we consider limits with respect to these posets, i.~e.,
intersections
\begin{equation}\label{eq4}\begin{array}{cc}\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}, & \bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},\lambda}, \\
\, & \, \\ \bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h}, &
\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda}.
\end{array}
\end{equation}
Since these intersections can be represented as unions for {\em
completions}${\bf D}'_0$ of ${\bf D}_0$, obtained by adding of
complete theories $T$ to diagrams in ${\bf D}_0$, we can assume
that ${\bf D}_0$ is already {\em complete}\index{Class!complete},
i.~e., all diagrams in ${\bf D}_0$ contain a complete theory $T$.
Moreover, since all neighborhoods are singletons for complete
classes having finite generic structures, we shall additionally
assume that $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structures are infinite.
In such a case, intersections (\ref{eq4}) contain isomorphism
types of models of $T$ realizing sets of types $[\Phi(A)]^A_X$ for
$\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0$. Thus, the problem of description for
intersections (\ref{eq4}) is reduced to the problem of description
for models of $T$ realizing a given set of types.

By L\"{o}wenheim--Skolem theorem, intersections
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$
have models of unbounded cardinalities, are not sets, and, in
particular, can not be singletons. By same reason, intersections
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda}$ are not singletons for $\lambda>{\rm
max}\{|\Sigma|,\omega\}$, as well as we have at least two
structures in $\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\omega}$ if a $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structure $\mathcal{M}$ is at most
countable and there are types in $S(T)$ that are not realized by
diagrams in ${\bf D}_0$. At the same time, if a countable $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structure $\mathcal{M}$ is saturated then
 $\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\omega}$ is a singleton
containing the isomorphism type of $\mathcal{M}$, since there
exists unique homogeneous structure realizing exactly given set of
types. Thus we have

\begin{theorem}\label{thm3} Let $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ be a complete
self-sufficient generic class and $\mathcal{M}$ be a countable
$({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structure. The following conditions
are equivalent:

$1)$ $\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\omega}$ is a singleton {\rm (}consisting of the
isomorphism type of $\mathcal{M}${\rm )};

$2)$ the structure $\mathcal{M}$ is saturated.
\end{theorem}
Theorem \ref{thm3} means that intersection of neighborhoods for
isomorphism types of countable homogeneous models contains unique
limit point if and only if this point, being a generic limit,
corresponds to the saturated model.

\begin{definition}\label{defg6} {\rm \cite{Be} A type $p(\bar{x})\in S(T)$ is said to be
\emph{powerful}\index{Type!powerful} in~a~theory $T$ if every
model $\mathcal{M}$ of $T$ realizing $p$ also realizes every type
$q\in S(T)$, that is, $\mathcal{M}\models S(T)$.}
\end{definition}
By Theorem \ref{thm3}, the set $Z=\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},\omega}$ is a singleton if and
only if it consists only of isomorphism type of a saturated
structure $\mathcal{M}$. Since there exists a countable saturated
structure $\mathcal{M}$ if and only if the theory $T={\rm
Th}(\mathcal{M})$ is small (i.~e., $|S(T)|=\omega$), and all
countable models of small $T$ are isomorphic to unions of
elementary chains of prime models over tuples \cite{SuLP, SuCCMCT}(these unions are either again prime models over tuples or {\em
limit} models), we have $|Z|=1$ if and only if $T$ is either
countably categorical or $T$ does not have powerful types and
there is unique, up to isomorphism, union of elementary chains of
prime models over tuples which realizes all types in $S(T)$.

Indeed, if $T$ is countably categorical then $|Z|=1$. If there are
no powerful types, the uniqueness of considered elementary chains
implies that $Z$ is a singleton consisting of isomorphism type of
saturated model. Conversely, if $T$ is not countably categorical
and there is a powerful type $p$ then the isomorphism type of
model $\mathcal{M}_p$, prime over a realization of $p$, belongs to
$Z$. We have $\mathcal{M}_p\not\simeq\mathcal{M}$, isomorphism
types for $\mathcal{M}_p$ and $\mathcal{M}$ both belong to $Z$,
whence $|Z|\geq 2$. We get again the inequality $|Z|\geq 2$ if
there are at least two non-isomorphic unions of elementary chains
of prime models over tuples. Thus we have

\begin{theorem}\label{thm4} Let $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ be a complete
self-sufficient generic class and $\mathcal{M}$ be a countable
$({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structure. The following conditions
are equivalent:

$1)$ $\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\omega}$ is a singleton {\rm (}consisting of the isomorphism
type of $\mathcal{M}${\rm )};

$2)$ the structure $\mathcal{M}$ is saturated and the theory
$T={\rm Th}(\mathcal{M})$ is either countably categorical or there
are no powerful types of $T$ and there is unique, up to
isomorphism, union of elementary chains of prime models over
tuples which realizes all types in $S(T)$.
\end{theorem}

Classification of countable models of complete theories
\cite{SuLP, SuCCMCT} allows to describe intersections $(1)$ for
countable models as well as links between them. We consider the
description for theories $T$ with finite Rudin--Keisler preorders.
It is known \cite{SuLP, SuCCMCT} that every countable model of $T$
is either prime over a finite set or limit over a type. Recall
that the preordered set ${\rm CM}(T)$\index{${\rm CM}(T)$}
consists of all isomorphism types of countable models of $T$ and
the Rudin--Keisler preorder $\leq_{\rm RK}$ defined by the
following way: for isomorphism types ${\bf M}_1$ and ${\bf M}_2$,
${\bf M}_1\leq_{\rm RK}{\bf M}_2$ if and only if for models
$\mathcal{M}_1\in{\bf M}_1$ and $\mathcal{M}_2\in{\bf M}_2$,
$\mathcal{M}_2$ realizes all types in $S(\emptyset)$ being
realized in $\mathcal{M}_1$. Thus the Rudin--Keisler preorders
$\leq_{\rm RK}$ define links between models reflecting
corresponding links between sets of realized types. Moreover, for
finite Rudin--Keisler preorders, each ${\rm RK}$-class contains at
most one isomorphism type of homogeneous model, having a
homogeneous model in a ${\rm RK}$-class containing limit models
that homogeneous model is also limit \cite{Gav5}, and the
following theorems hold:

\begin{theorem}\label{thm5} \cite{SuCCMCT} The set of isomorphism
types for countable model of an arbitrary small theory $T$ with a
finite Rudin--Keisler preorder has a partition into classes
$\widetilde{\bf PM}\cup{\bf L}$ forming a partially ordered set
${\rm CM}(T)$ with a least and a greatest elements, where
$\widetilde{\bf PM}$ are sets of isomorphism types for prime
models over tuples, ${\bf L}$ are isomorphism types of limit
models related to $\widetilde{\bf PM}$. Each class $\widetilde{\bf
PM}\cup{\bf L}$ contains at most one isomorphism type of
homogeneous model. Moreover, the following conditions are
satisfied:

{\rm (a)} the least element of ${\rm CM}(T)$ is a singleton and
contains the isomorphism type of prime model;

{\rm (b)} the greatest element of ${\rm CM}(T)$ contains the
isomorphism type of the homogeneous saturated model, which is
limit if $|{\rm CM}(T)|>1$;

{\rm (c)} each element $\widetilde{\bf PM}\cup{\bf L}$ is either a
singleton and does not contain isomorphism types of limit models,
or the sets $\widetilde{\bf PM}$ and ${\bf L}$ are non-empty and,
having a homogeneous model, the isomorphism type of that
homogeneous model belongs to ${\bf L}$.
\end{theorem}\begin{theorem}\label{thm6} \cite{SuCCMCT} For any finite partially
ordered set $\langle X;\leq\rangle$ with a least and a greatest
elements, there is a small theory $T$ such that the restriction
${\rm CM}(T)_h$ of ${\rm CM}(T)$ to the set of isomorphism types
of homogeneous models of $T$ is isomorphic to $\langle
X;\leq\rangle$.
\end{theorem}
Let $T$ be a generic theory, ${\bf D}$ be the class of all
complete self-sufficient generic classes ${\bf D}_0$ such that $T$
is $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic for appropriate $\preceq$. Denote
by $\mathfrak{B}(T)_{\rm Iso}$\index{$\mathfrak{B}(T)_{\rm Iso}$}
the structure $\langle B(T)_{\rm Iso};\leq\rangle$, where
$B(T)_{\rm Iso}$ consists of all intersections
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{\rm Iso}$
for ${\bf D}_0\in{\bf D}$, and $\leq\,=\,\subseteq$. Similarly we
denote by $\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm
Iso},\lambda}$\index{$\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},\lambda}$} the
structure $\langle B(T)_{{\rm Iso},\lambda};\leq\rangle$, where
$B(T)_{{\rm Iso},\lambda}$ consists of all intersections
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\lambda};$ by $\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm
Iso},h}$\index{$\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},h}$} the structure
$\langle B(T)_{{\rm Iso},h};\leq\rangle$, \ where \ $B(T)_{{\rm
Iso},h}$\ consists \ of \ all \ intersections \
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h},$ and $\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda}$\index{$\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}$} is
the structure $\langle B(T)_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda};\leq\rangle$,
where $B(T)_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}$ consists of all intersections \
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda},$${\bf D}_0\in{\bf D}$, \ $\leq\,=\,\subseteq$.

\newcommand{\isom}{\,\mbox{\raisebox{0.7\height}{$\sim$}}\!\!\!\!\!%
\mbox{\raisebox{-0.4\height}{$\to$}}\,}
Note that for any $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic structure
$\mathcal{M}$ and for any $({\bf D}'_0;\preceq')$-generic
structure $\mathcal{M}'$, where ${\bf D}_0,{\bf D}'_0\in{\bf D}$
and $|M|\leq|M'|\leq\lambda$, $\mathcal{M}$ is elementary
embeddable in $\mathcal{M}'$ if and only if all types realized in
$\mathcal{M}$ are also realized in $\mathcal{M}'$. It means that
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda}\supseteq \bigcap\limits_{\Phi'(A')\in{\bf
D}'_0}[\![\Phi'(A')]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\lambda}.$ Thus, for any
countable complete theory $T$ without finite models, we have a
canonical isomorphism $\phi$ between the poset ${\rm CM}(T)_h$ and
the poset $\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},h,\omega}$ mapping the
isomorphism type of countable $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$-generic
homogeneous model $\mathcal{M}$ to $\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},h,\omega}$. Having the isomorphism
$\phi\mbox{\rm : }{\rm CM}(T)_h\isom \mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm
Iso},h,\omega}$, by Theorem \ref{thm6}, we get

\begin{theorem}\label{thm7} For any finite partially ordered set
$\langle X;\leq\rangle$ with a least and a greatest elements,
there is a small theory $T$ such that the structure
$\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},h,\omega}$ is isomorphic to $\langle
X;\leq\rangle$.
\end{theorem}\medskip
Using \ Theorem \ \ref{thm5}\ the \ isomorphism \ $\phi$\
produces the isomorphism \ $\psi\mbox{\rm : }{\rm CM}(T)_h\isom
\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},\omega}$ such that
$\psi(x)=\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\omega}$ for $x\in{\rm CM}(T)_h$ with
$\phi(x)=\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\omega}.$
Thus we obtain the following

\begin{theorem}\label{thm8} For any finite partially ordered set
$\langle X;\leq\rangle$ with a least and a greatest elements,
there is a small theory $T$ such that the structure
$\mathfrak{B}(T)_{{\rm Iso},\omega}$ is isomorphic to $\langle
X;\leq\rangle$.
\end{theorem}

In this section we consider complete countable theories $T$
without finite models.

As usual we denote by $I(T,\lambda)$ the {\em spectrum
function}\index{Spectrum function} giving the number of
non-isomorphic models $\mathcal{M}$ of $T$ with
$|\mathcal{M}|=\lambda$. It is known that
$I(T,\omega)\in(\omega\setminus\{0,2\})\cup\{\omega,\omega_1,2^\omega\}$.

Clearly, if $T$ has a prime model $\mathcal{M}_0$ being $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic for a complete self-sufficient class $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$, then $\left|\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm Iso},\omega}\right|=I(T,\omega).
$
Thus this cardinality belongs to
$(\omega\setminus\{0,2\})\cup\{\omega,\omega_1,2^\omega\}$.

More generally, for any $\lambda\geq\omega$ we have
\begin{equation}\label{eq5}\left|\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf
D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},\lambda}\right|=\sum\limits_{\omega\leq\mu\leq\lambda}I(T,\mu).
\end{equation}
Using correspondences, as in Section 3, for homogeneous models and
neighborhoods for generic classes, the equality (\ref{eq5}) can be
adapted for an arbitrary generic class.

\medskip
Let $\beta$ be an ordinal number, $\lambda$ a limit ordinal
number, and $\kappa$ a cardinal number. We define
$\Im_\beta(\kappa)$ recursively: $\Im_0(\kappa)=\kappa$,
$\Im_{\beta+1}(\kappa)=2^{\Im_{\beta}(\kappa)}$, and
$\Im_{\lambda}(\kappa)=\bigcup\limits_{\beta<\lambda}\Im_{\beta}(\kappa)$.

\begin{theorem}\label{thm9} \cite{Sh, HHL} For any complete theory $T$
in a countable language and without finite models the uncountable
spectrum $\aleph_\alpha\mapsto I(T,\aleph_\alpha)$ {\rm
(}$\alpha>0${\rm )} is the minimum of the map
$\aleph_\alpha\mapsto 2^{\aleph_\alpha}$ and one of the following
maps:

$1)$ $2^{\aleph_\alpha}$;

$2)$ $\Im_{d+1}(|\alpha+\omega|)$ for some
$d\in[\omega,\omega_1)$;

$3)$ $\Im_{d-1}(|\alpha+\omega|^{2^{\aleph_0}})$ for some finite
$d>0$;

$4)$ $\Im_{d-1}(|\alpha+\omega|^{\aleph_0}+\Im_2(\aleph_0))$ for
some finite $d>0$;

$5)$ $\Im_{d-1}(|\alpha+\omega|+\Im_2(\aleph_0))$ for some finite
$d>0$;

$6)$ $\Im_{d-1}(|\alpha+\omega|^{\aleph_0})$ for some finite
$d>0$;

$7)$ $\Im_{d-1}(|\alpha+\omega|+2^{\aleph_0})$ for some finite
$d>1$;

$8)$ $\Im_{d-1}(|\alpha+\omega|)$ for some finite $d>0$;

$9)$ $\Im_{d-2}(|\alpha+\omega|^{|\alpha+1|})$ for some finite
$d>1$;

$10)$ identically $\Im_2(\aleph_0)$;

$11)$ $|\alpha|$ for infinite $\alpha$ and, for finite $\alpha$,
$|(\alpha+1)^n/G|-|\alpha^n/G|$ for some finite $n>1$ and some
normal subgroup $G$ of ${\rm Sym}(n)$;

$12)$ identically $1$.

Each of these $12$ possibilities occurs as the spectrum of some
complete theory in a countable language.
\end{theorem}
By \ Theorem \ \ref{thm9}\ we \ have \ an \ explicit \
description \ for \ the \ sum \
$\sum\limits_{\omega\leq\mu\leq\lambda}I(T,\mu)$ in (\ref{eq5}).

\medskip
Following \cite{Kuda1, Kuda2} we denote by $H_T(\lambda)$ the
number of non-isomorphic $\omega$-homogeneous models $\mathcal{M}$
of $T$ with $|\mathcal{M}|=\lambda$. The description of functions
$H_T(\lambda)$ allows to observe the cardinalities for
$\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda}$. In particular, for a complete self-sufficient
generic class $({\bf D}_0;\preceq)$ producing a prime $({\bf
D}_0;\preceq)$-generic model $\mathcal{M}_0$ of $T$, we have
$$\left|\bigcap\limits_{\Phi(A)\in{\bf D}_0}[\![\Phi(A)]\!]_{{\rm
Iso},h,\lambda}\right|=\sum\limits_{\omega\leq\mu\leq\lambda}H_T(\mu).
$$\bigskip
